titleStmt.title: Acid sphingomyelinase mediates murine acute lung injury following transfusion of aged platelets

analytic.title: Acid sphingomyelinase mediates murine acute lung injury following transfusion of aged platelets

biblStruct.note: Submitted 27 July 2016; accepted in final form 6 March 2017

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

p.s: Pulmonary complications from stored blood products are the leading cause of mortality related to transfusion.
Transfusion-related acute lung injury is mediated by antibodies or bioactive mediators, yet underlying mechanisms are incompletely understood.
Sphingolipids such as ceramide regulate lung injury, and their composition changes as a function of time in stored blood.
Here, we tested the hypothesis that aged platelets may induce lung injury via a sphingolipid-mediated mechanism.
To assess this hypothesis, a two-hit mouse model was devised.

Recipient mice were treated with 2 mg/kg intraperitoneal lipopolysaccharide (priming) 2 h before transfusion of 10 ml/kg stored (1-5 days) platelets treated with or without addition of acid sphingomyelinase inhibitor ARC39 or platelets from acid sphingomyelinase-deficient mice, which both reduce ceramide formation.
Transfused mice were examined for signs of pulmonary neutrophil accumulation, endothelial barrier dysfunction, and histological evidence of lung injury.
Sphingolipid profiles in stored platelets were analyzed by mass spectrophotometry.
Transfusion of aged platelets into primed mice induced characteristic features of lung injury, which increased in severity as a function of storage time.
Ceramide accumulated in platelets during storage, but this was attenuated by ARC39 or in acid sphingomyelinase-deficient platelets.
Compared with wild-type platelets, transfusion of ARC39-treated or acid sphingomyelinase-deficient aged platelets alleviated lung injury.
Aged platelets elicit lung injury in primed recipient mice, which can be alleviated by pharmacological inhibition or genetic deletion of acid sphingomyelinase.
Interventions targeting sphingolipid formation represent a promising strategy to increase the safety and longevity of stored blood products.
transfusion-related acute lung injury; ceramide; acid sphingomyelinase; platelets; storage
plasma-containing blood products, has the highest mortality (5-15%) of all transfusion-related complications (19,25,61).
Its incidence ranges between 0.02 and 1.12% per transfused blood product and exceeds 5% in high-risk groups such as the critically ill (61).
TRALI is considered a disease mediated primarily by transmission of antibodies that activate recipient immune responses (34).

This is based on documented presence of donor anti-HLA class I and granulocyte antibodies in 72-89% of patients with TRALI (37) and reproducible induction of TRALI in mice by infusion of MHC class I antibodies (26).
However, the majority of patients receiving blood products containing pathogenic antibodies do not develop TRALI (19,34,57).
Furthermore, TRALI has been documented in the absence of detectable pathogenic antibodies within donor products or recipients (37,45,49).

Antibody-independent mechanisms are estimated to account for 10 -15% of TRALI cases (2,14,45), yet the relevance of bioactive mediators other than antibodies in donor blood products may be considerably higher because the mere presence of antibodies does not prove their mechanistic involvement (34,37).

Preclinical TRALI studies in rats and sheep transfused with cell-free supernatants from aged platelets (44,59,62) or red blood cells (51,63) demonstrate that TRALI may be triggered by soluble mediators other than antibodies released during storage as a function of time (13,31).
The search for soluble mediators has focused predominantly on bioactive lipids, with specific emphasis on lysophosphatidyl choline (LPC) because of its presence in stored blood products (46,49).
However, mechanistic proof for the lipid hypothesis is lacking, and lipid species other than LPC have not been considered in greater depth so far.
Recent lipidomic analyses of stored human platelets reveal greater increases in the sphingolipid ceramide than LPC after 5 days of storage (36,40).

Ceramide, which in platelets is predominantly produced from sphingomyelin by the enzyme acid sphingomyelinase (ASM), has recently been identified by us and others as a key mediator of ALI (9,41,52,67).
We thus hypothesized that stored platelets may induce antibody-independent TRALI through increased formation of ceramide by ASM as a function of storage time.

To test this hypothesis, we developed a murine platelet transfusion model incorporating the two-hit concept of antibody-independent TRALI (64) based on clinical observations that preexisting inflammation enhances the recipients' risk of TRALI (55,61).
In this model, a first hit of systemic lipopolysaccharide (LPS) is followed by transfusion of either fresh or aged platelets.

Compared with wild-type platelets, transfusion of aged platelets stored with pharmacological inhibition or genetic deletion of ceramideforming ASM prevented signs of lung injury, thus identifying ceramide as a mediator of TRALI.

All experiments were performed in accordance with the Guide for the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals (Institute of Laboratory Animal Resources, 1996) following approval by the Animal Care Committee of the Keenan Research Centre at St Michael's Hospital.
Platelet donors consisted of 8-to 12-wk-old male C57BL/6 mice (Charles River Laboratories, Montreal, Quebec, Canada) or ASM-deficient (smpd1 Ϫ/Ϫ ) mice.
Transfusion recipient mice were 8-to12-wk-old (22-30 g body weight) male BALB/c mice (Charles River Laboratories).

Before experiments, mice were kept for at least 1 wk of acclimatization in cages of up to five mice per cage with free access to chow (2918 irradiated Laboratory Diet; Harland, Mississauga, Ontario, Canada) and water on a 12-h:12-h day/night cycle at 22°C.
Preparation and storage of mouse platelets.

Donor platelets were isolated from platelet-rich plasma (PRP) from pools of citrated [10% citrate-phosphate-dextrose-adenine (CPDA, C4431; Sigma, Oakville, Ontario, Canada) phosphate buffered saline (PBS)) diluted whole blood from five male C57BL/6 or smpd1 Ϫ/Ϫ anesthetized [2% intraperitoneal 2,2,2 tribromoethanol (Sigma)] mice by cardiac puncture (25-gauge needle) as previously reported (1).
PRP was collected by centrifugation (200 g for 15 min at room temperature) of whole blood three times consecutively before being combined after pelleting at 1,000 g for 18 min at room temperature.

Pooled platelets were enumerated by impedance counting (LH 780 Analyzer; Beckman Coulter, Mississauga, Ontario, Canada) to allow standardized final storage concentrations of 1 ϫ 10 9 platelets/ml in 40% plasma and 50% sterile PBS with 10% CPDA.

Platelets were swirled horizontally by an orbital shaker at room temperature throughout storage in a sterile biosafety cabinet as described previously (1) in the absence or presence of the ASM inhibitor ARC39 (10 mol/l) (39).
The number of red blood cells present in stored platelets from different pools was 13.3 Ϯ 1.8 ϫ 10 6 /ml (means Ϯ SE; n ϭ 12).
Platelets were isolated in a similar fashion to previous experiments in which white blood cell contamination had been shown to be 1.1 Ϯ 0.3 white blood cells/l (1).
To assess for signs of bacterial contamination, stored platelets (50 l) were added to lysogeny broth culture plates incubated at 37°C for 48 h to assess for colony formation.
Platelet characterization.
Donor platelets were counted and sized (mean platelet volume; MPV) based on impedance (LH 780 Analyzer).

Platelets were assayed by flow cytometry (Fortessa X-20 SORP; BD Biosciences, San Jose, CA) to assess forward and side scatter, CD41 [integrin ␣2b conjugated to phycoerythrin (133906 MWReg30; Biolegend, San Diego, CA)], and CD62p [P-selectin conjugated to fluorescein isothiocyanate (FITC) (553744 RB40.1134;
BD Biosciences)] surface expression.
Murine platelet transfusion.
Two hours before transfusion, recipient mice were primed (1st hit) with 2 mg/kg 0111:B4 phenol extracted Escherichia coli LPS (L2630, lot no.
095M4165V; Sigma) or an equivalent volume of normal saline (NS) by intraperitoneal (i.p.) injection.
Mice were transfused intravenously (i.v.) by slow tail vein injection over 60 s with 10 ml/kg of 1 ϫ 10 9 allogeneic murine platelets/ml stored for 1-7 days or equal volumes of NS (2nd hit).
Mice were monitored in their cages at room temperature for 6 h until necropsy.
Analysis of recipient mouse TRALI.

At necropsy, mice were anesthetized with i.p. midazolam (5 mg/kg body wt, Dormicum; Roche, Basel, Switzerland), fentanyl (0.05 mg/kg body wt; Janssen-Cilag, Neuss, Germany), and medetomidine (0.5 mg/kg body wt, Domitor; Dr. E. Graeub, Basel, Switzerland) and briefly ventilated (tidal volume 8 ml/kg; fraction of inspired oxygen 21%; respiratory rate 110 breaths/min; positive end-expiratory pressure 3 cm H2O; MiniVent; Harvard Apparatus, Holliston, MA) for 10 min via tracheotomy tube (Portex fine bore polyethylene tubing 0.58 mm ID/0.96
OD; Smith Medical International, Kent, UK).

A midline thoracotomy established access to place a silk tie around the right lung hilum to allow for isolated left lung bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) by a single slow instillation and subsequent recovery of 500 l of warmed sterile saline via a 20-gauge needle attached to the plastic tracheal tube.
Recovered BAL aspirates were Ͼ80% of the instillate with a standard deviation of 3.7%.

BAL fluid was spun at 600 g for 5 min at room temperature to remove cells and debris and then frozen at Ϫ80°C until assessment for total protein [Bio-Rad protein assay (CAT-500-0006; Bio-Rad, Mississauga, Ontario, Canada)], ELISA determination of macrophage inflammatory protein 2 (MIP-2␣; mouse CXCL2/MIP-2 Quantikine Kit, no.

MM200, sensitivity Ͼ1.5 pg/mL; R & D Systems, Burlington, Ontario, Canada), thrombin-anti-thrombin complexes ELISA (TATc, Behring, detection limit 62.5 pg/ml), and tumor necrosis-␣ (TNF-␣; mouse TNF-␣ Quantikine ELISA Kit, detection limit 62.5 pg/ml; R & D Systems) as directed by the manufacturers.
From the right lower lobe, wet-to-dry lung weight ratio was assessed as described previously (15).
Wet-to-dry lung weight ratios obtained from right lower lobes were calculated as net wet weight over net dry weight after 30 min of drying by microwave.
Myeloperoxidase (MPO) enzyme activity as a measure of neutrophil infiltration was assessed in the right middle lobe as previously described (20).
In brief, Ϫ80°C lung tissues were thawed in ice-cold 0.02 mol/l potassium phosphate buffer with 5 mmol/l N-ethylmaleimide (ETM 222.5;
Bioshop Burlington, Ontario, Canada; pH 7.4), minced, and homogenized (PRO Scientific 200 homogenizer; Oxford, CT).
Homogenized samples were centrifuged at 10,000 g for 20 min at 4°C, and supernatants were discarded.

Pellets were resuspended in ice-cold 0.05 mol/l potassium phosphate buffer with 0.5% hexadecyltrimethylammonium bromide (Sigma Aldrich; pH 6.0) and received three cycles of snap freeze/thaw and sonication (Model 300; Fischer Scientific, Ottawa, Ontario, Canada).
Samples were then centrifuged at 8,000 g for 20 min at 4°C, after which pellets were discarded, and supernatants were isolated for quantification of MPO activity.
Samples were then incubated with 3,3=,5,5=-tetramethylbenzidine (301.1;
Bioshop) dissolved in dimethyl sulfoxide (Sigma Aldrich) and hydrogen peroxide in a 0.08 mol/l sodium phosphate buffer (pH 5.4).

Change in photometric absorbance was measured at 405 nm by spectrophotometry, and MPO activity in lung tissue samples was referenced to a standard curve derived from horseradish peroxidase (H3410; Sigma Aldrich) to yield units of MPO activity per mass of lung tissue.
Right upper lobes were formalin (Caledon Chemicals, Georgetown, Ontario, Canada) fixed, paraffin embedded, sectioned by microtome (5 m), and stained by hematoxylin and eosin.

Lung slides were graded by a single blinded investigator using a histological lung injury score based on the presence of alveolar or interstitial neutrophils, hyaline membranes, airspace debris, and alveolar septal thickening (29).
Images were captured on a LaborLux S microscope (Leitz, Wetzler, Germany) with a Tuscen IS 130 (Fuzhou, Fujian, China) camera.
At time of death, mice were exsanguinated by cardiac puncture (25-gauge needle) after receiving an overdose of intraperitoneal anesthetic.

Whole blood from cardiac puncture was collected in syringes primed with 50 U of unfractionated heparin (Pharmaceutical Partners of Canada, Richmond Hill, Ontario, Canada) and then transferred into citrated tubes and spun at 600 g for 5 min to isolate plasma, which was stored at Ϫ80°C for TNF-␣ analyses (mouse TNF-␣ Quantikine ELISA Kit, detection limit 62.5 pg/ml; R & D Systems).
Platelet lipid profiles.
Ceramides were extracted and quantified from stored donor platelet supernatants using liquid chromatography followed by mass spectrophotometry as described (3,12).

In brief, frozen (Ϫ80°C) platelets were thawed and spun at 1,000 g for 15 min at room temperature to allow collection of lipids from the organic phase from a CHCl 3:CH3OH extraction spiked with ceramide 17 (C17:0) as an internal standard.

Sphingolipid analysis involved assessment of C16:0, C18:0, C20:0, C22:0, C24:0, and C24:1 by rapid-resolution liquid chromatography and tandem mass spectroscopy using a Q-TOF 6530 mass spectrometer (Agilent Technologies, Waldbronn, Germany) operating in the positive electrospray ionization mode.
Quantification was performed with Mass Hunter Software (Agilent Technologies).
Statistical analysis.
All data are depicted as means (Ϯ SE).
Comparisons involved Student's two-tailed t-test and one-or two-way ANOVA followed respectively by all pairwise Tukey's or Bonferroni tests.
P Ͻ 0.05 was considered statistically significant.
Statistical analysis was performed using Prism (version 5.01; GraphPad Software, La Jolla, CA).

div.head: Platelet transfusion causes TRALI as a function of storage

p.s: primed recipient mice, including increases in wet-to-dry lung weight ratio (Fig. 1A) and BAL protein content (Fig. 1B) as indicators of lung edema formation and vascular barrier failure, increased lung MPO activity (Fig. 1C) signifying neutrophil infiltration, and histological signs of lung injury (Fig. 1, D and E).

TRALI severity correlated with duration of platelet storage before transfusion, albeit the duration of storage time required to induce a significant change varied for individual parameters between 1 and 5 days.

When assessing the time course of TRALI development and resolution following infusion of 5-day-stored platelets in LPS-primed recipient mice, the maximal increase in wet-to-dry lung weight ratio and histological evidence of lung injury were observed 6 h after transfusion with a relative recovery by 24 h (Fig. 2).
Accordingly, 6 h posttransfusion was set as the end point for all subsequent experiments.

BAL TATc levels assessed 6 h after platelet transfusion, on the other hand, showed no significant differences between controls, LPS-primed mice, or mice transfused with either fresh or aged platelets, thus giving no evidence for excess pulmonary coagulopathy in our two-hit model (data not shown).

div.head: Recipient inflammation acts as a first hit to enhance transfusion-related ALI.

p.s: To determine the contribution of LPS in the induction of TRALI, in keeping with the two-hit concept of TRALI, we next assessed the contribution of priming with an inflammatory first hit before induction of lung injury by aged, stored platelets.

In the absence of transfusion, LPS caused mild lung inflammation as indicated by modest increases in lung MPO activity and histological scores, and a significant increase in plasma TNF-␣ levels (82.1 Ϯ 24 pg/ml after LPS vs. undetectable in control mice; n ϭ 5 each) (P ϭ 0.027) but no signs of lung edema or barrier failure (Fig. 3).

Furthermore, aged platelets without LPS yielded only moderate increases in lung edema formation and histological evidence of lung injury, whereas no significant effects on MPO activity, BAL protein content (Fig. 3), or BAL levels of the proinflammatory cytokine MIP-2␣ (Fig. 4) were observed.

Transfusion of aged platelets into LPS-primed recipient mice, however, caused a synergistic increase in lung inflammation and injury, including wet-todry lung weight ratio, lung MPO activity, histological evidence of lung injury (Fig. 3), and BAL levels of MIP-2␣
Recipient inflammation thus heightened TRALI reactions in the present model.
Ceramide accumulates in stored murine platelets as a function of time.

As a potential mechanism by which stored blood products may trigger TRALI, we next assessed changes in sphingolipid composition and specifically the accumulation of ceramide as a function of storage time in murine platelets.

Quantitative analysis of sphingolipid profiles in donor platelet samples by liquid chromatography followed by mass spectroscopy revealed a progressive accumulation of the ceramide species C16:0, C18:0, C22:0, C24:0, and C24:1 over storage time, with total increases ranging between 1.6-and 2.9-fold between day 0 and day 7 of platelet storage (Fig. 5).
ASM inhibition or deletion in stored platelets attenuates TRALI.

To probe for the mechanistic relevance of sphingolipids in the TRALI response to stored platelets, we next applied two independent approaches, in that we blocked ceramide formation from ASM in stored platelets by either pharmacologic inhibition (ARC39-treated platelets) or genetic deletion (smpd1 -/platelets) of ASM.

Both strategies significantly reduced lung MPO activity and histological signs of lung injury following infusion of day 5 platelets and normalized wet-to-dry lung weight ratio and BAL protein levels (Fig. 6).

Notably, the protective effects of ARC39 treatment persisted when ARC39treated platelets were washed and resuspended in PBS before transfusion (data not shown), indicating that the effects were not attributable to transfusion of ARC39 itself into recipient mice.
ASM deficiency permits extended storage of platelets with reduced signs of TRALI in recipient mice.
up new perspectives, in that it may, not only increase the safety of transfusions, but also potentially allow extension of blood product storage time.
To test the latter notion, we prolonged platelet storage to 7 days and probed whether ASM deficiency may still provide protection.
Storage of platelets for 7 days did not increase the rate of infections, as culture of 7-day-stored platelets on lysogeny broth plates revealed no growth after 48 h (data not shown).

Infusion of platelets stored for 7 days reproduced characteristic features of lung injury, including increased wet-to-dry lung weight ratio, protein extravasation into BAL, lung MPO activity, and histological evidence of lung injury (Fig. 7).

Transfusion of smpd1 Ϫ/Ϫ platelets stored 7 days attenuated some signs of TRALI, in that it reduced wet-to-dry lung weight ratio and histological lung injury; however, it failed to normalize lung MPO activity.

Importantly, ASM-targeted interventions (ARC39 or smpd1 Ϫ/Ϫ platelets) did not alter the total number of platelets throughout storage or affect general markers of platelet activation for up to 7 days of storage compared with wild-type platelets (Table 1).

MPV showed lower values immediately after isolation at day 0 in all groups; however, MPV rapidly increased to levels similar to those previously reported for C57BL/6 mice (32) and remained constant throughout 7 days of storage (Table 1).

Throughout storage, the percentage of CD62p ϩ cells as an activation marker for CD41 ϩ platelets increased progressively and in parallel in all groups (Table 1), indicating that the protective effects of ASM-targeted interventions were independent of storage-dependent platelet activation.

Rather, ASM inhibition by ARC39 or ASM deficiency in smpd1 Ϫ/Ϫ platelets prevented the accumulation of select ceramide species, including C16:0, C22:0, and C24:0 (Fig. 8), as a function of storage time, consistent with the notion that these interventions conferred protection from antibody-independent TRALI by preventing the excess formation of injurious sphingolipid species in stored blood products.
Ceramide C18:0, C18:1, C20:0, and C24:1 were either undetectable or did not differ significantly between experimental groups (data not shown).

Here, we report a novel mechanism of antibody-independent TRALI that is triggered by aged stored platelets and mediated by ASM-dependent formation and accumulation of ceramide in stored blood products.

In a newly established mouse model, infusion of murine donor platelets induced characteristic signs of TRALI when administered within 6 h of transfusion in LPS-primed recipient mice as evidenced by the formation of lung edema, vascular barrier failure, pulmonary neutrophil accumulation, and histological evidence of lung injury.
In LPS-primed animals, TRALI severity increased as a function of platelet storage time.

ASM-dependent ceramide generation appears to play an important role in the synergy between LPS and stored platelets, as prevention of ceramide formation by either pharmacological inhibition of ASM or platelets from smpd1 Ϫ/Ϫ donor mice resulted in a marked attenuation of TRALI symptoms, even when platelet storage time was extended up to 7 days.

Our findings therefore identify ASMderived ceramide species as a key mechanism of antibodyindependent TRALI following transfusion of aged stored platelets and suggest ASM-targeted interventions as a promising strategy to increase the safety and longevity of stored blood products.
Murine model of antibody-independent TRALI following transfusion of aged stored murine platelets.
Platelets have established roles in hemostasis and immune function but have also been mechanistically implicated in lung injury [recently reviewed (66)].
Platelets collected for transfusion are a scarce clinical resource and are thus often stored as long as possible to maximize their availability.
Prolonged storage of platelets, however, may increase the risk of TRALI.
Although red blood cells are more frequently transfused and thus often associated with TRALI, platelets have a higher product-specific risk of causing TRALI (31,61).

Here, we established a novel murine model of TRALI in which transfusion of aged platelets led to alveolo-capillary barrier failure with increasing lung edema and pulmonary neutrophil accumulation within 6 h, which coincides with accepted timing and mechanisms of human TRALI (58).
In time profile analyses, TRALI symptoms reached a maximum at 6 h with subsequent resolution at 24 h posttransfusion.

Notably, onset of TRALI in the clinical scenario can vary considerably between Ͻ2 h (48) up to 24 h posttransfusion (28), presumably attributable to multifactorial factors, which are, however, little understood as of yet.
Within these constraints, our present model roughly matches the temporal progression of disease in TRALI survivors (58).

In contrast to aged platelets, transfusion of equal volumes of crystalloid solution or fresh platelets caused no signs of lung injury, effectively ruling out transfusion-associated circulatory overload (53) as an alternative cause of lung edema.

The dose transfused (2.5 ϫ 10 8 platelets per 25-g mouse) corresponds to 6 ϫ 10 11 platelets (2 adult pools; 10 ml/kg) for a 70-kg human (1,43), which is lower than doses used in clinical trials (54) and other animal models (23), stressing again the clinical relevance of the model.
Compared with previous TRALI studies based on transfusion of aged human platelets or human platelet supernatants into rats, mice, or sheep, the present
approach avoids potential adverse effects of xenobiotic transfusions (44,59) or the requirement of immunodeficient recipient animals (4,7,45).
Our approach is similar to a recently reported model of antibody-independent TRALI using transfusion of aged stored platelets into LPS-primed rats (62).
In contrast to the corresponding rat model ( 62), TRALI mice did not exhibit signs of marked coagulopathy, as BAL TATc levels did not differ between groups.
Importantly, the use of a murine model has allowed us to investigate potential mechanisms of TRALI, taking advantage of genetically defined animals.
Continued investigation of TRALI will be facilitated using this animal model.

Recipient factors involving inflammation include chronic alcohol use, smoking, elevated IL-8 levels, liver surgery, or mechanical ventilation with high airway pressures increasing the risk for human TRALI (55,56).

This notion has given rise to the two-hit concept in which recipient inflammation recruits and partially activates neutrophils in the lung, allowing for exacerbated lung injury after a second hit by transfusion of blood products (64).
In the present model, we incorporated this concept, as recipient mice received proinflammatory priming by systemic infusion of LPS, which by itself caused a marked elevation in plasma TNF-␣.

Notably, the histological lung injury score was sensitive to LPS priming (1st hit), primarily attributable to an LPS-induced accumulation of neutrophils in the lung, which, in the absence of transfused platelets, however, failed to cause direct lung barrier disruption, in line with previous reports (30,60).
Despite the marked increase in

div.head: L631 histological lung injury score, LPS priming alone thus did not fulfill the criteria of lung injury as outlined in the 2011 Official American Thoracic Society Workshop Report for Features and Measurements of Experimental Acute Lung Injury in Animals,

p.s: which requires that at least three out of the following four main features of tissue injury need to be identified to positively determine lung injury, namely histological evidence of tissue injury, alteration of the alveolar capillary barrier, presence of an inflammatory response, and evidence of physiological dysfunction (29).

In contrast, capillary barrier failure and edema formation only became evident when aged (days 3-5) but not fresh (day 1) platelets were additionally transfused as second hit to LPS-primed recipient animals.

LPS priming, however, potentiated the TRALI response to aged platelet transfusion, in that transfusion of aged platelets in unprimed mice (without LPS) caused a moderate increase in wet-to-dry lung weight ratios and lung histology scores, which were potentiated when similarly aged platelets were transfused into LPS-primed mice.

Transfusion of aged platelets in LPS-primed mice also resulted in significant increases in lung MPO activity and BAL protein content, an effect that was not detectable with single hits of either LPS or aged platelets alone.
As such, the present findings lend further support to the two-hit concept of antibody-independent TRALI and concomitantly speak to the value of this model for the investigation of TRALI disease.
Donor sphingolipids dictate platelet-mediated TRALI severity.
By use of this new model, we identified a previously unrecognized role of sphingolipids in the induction of TRALI following transfusion of aged, stored platelets.

On the basis of the recognition that, not only plasma from aged platelets or red blood cells, but also lipid extracts and purified lipids from aged blood cells can induce characteristic signs of injury in isolated perfused rat lungs (44,51), formation and release of bioactive lipids have long been proposed as putative mechanisms underlying antibody-independent TRALI (47).
Considerable attention has specifically been paid to LPC because of its identifi- L632 cation in stored blood products (46) and its ability to prime neutrophils (47,50).

However, the LPC hypothesis has recently been challenged 1) as independent studies failed to detect LPC accumulation in stored blood products, which nevertheless induced TRALI-like symptoms (63, 65), 2) because prevention of LPC accumulation did not preclude neutrophil priming (65), or 3) based on the recognition that the previously proposed action of LPC via the PAF receptor and the resulting inhibition of neutrophil priming by LPC with the PAF receptor blocker WEB 2170 may be attributable to contaminating phospholipids (27).

Recent lipidomic analyses of stored human platelets revealed that the largest increase during 5 days of storage does in fact not occur in LPC (16 -32% increase at day 5 relative to day 0) but in ceramide (53-69%) (36,40).

Our studies show that the accumulation of ceramide in stored platelets is pertinent to TRALI, as we and others have previously shown ceramide to be an important mediator of endothelial barrier failure and lung injury (5, 9, 21, 22, 42).

Specifically, ceramide increases lung endothelial permeability by silencing constitutive endothelial nitric oxide synthase activity and recruitment of transient receptor potential 6 (TRPC6) channels to caveolae, resulting in endothelial Ca 2ϩ influx and subsequent barrier failure and edema formation (41,67).
In addition, ceramide promotes endothelial (35) but attenuates neutrophil apoptosis (24), thus further promoting barrier failure and inflammation.
Inhibition of ASM-dependent ceramide formation has accordingly been shown to prevent the development of ALI following stimulation with platelet-activating factor, endotoxin, or acid instillation (9).

The recognition of significant ceramide accumulation in platelets during storage in combination with the welldocumented role of ceramide as a key mechanism in the initiation of lung injury led us to postulate that targeting ASM may reduce the risk of TRALI from stored platelet preparations and thus increase the safety and longevity of stored blood products.

To test this hypothesis, we studied the effects of aged stored platelets in which ASM was either pharmacologically inhibited by ARC39 (39) or by use of aged stored platelets Group data are means Ϯ SE from n ϭ 5-8 independent pooled platelet samples each.

Wild-type (WT), ARC39-treated, and acid sphingomyelinase (ASM)-deficient (smpd1 Ϫ/Ϫ ; bottom) platelets were assessed in terms of number (count), size (mean platelet volume; MPV), and percentage of surface receptor expression for the platelet antigen CD41 and the platelet activation marker CD62p (P-selectin), respectively, serially throughout storage (0 -7 days).
*P Ͻ 0.05 vs. day 0 and †P Ͻ 0.05 vs. day 1, respectively, by 1-way ANOVA and post hoc Tukey's test.

ASM MEDIATES ANTIBODY-INDEPENDENT TRALI reduction of TRALI to levels similar to those seen in LPSprimed mice not receiving transfused platelets, thus identifying ASM-derived ceramide production as an important pathophysiological mechanism of antibody-independent TRALI.

Specifically, when LPS-primed mice were transfused with day 5 platelets that were treated with ARC39 or genetically deficient in ASM, vascular barrier function was completely restored as indicated by the normalization of wet-to-dry lung weight ratios and BAL protein levels.

Notably, markers associated with inflammation such as lung MPO activity and histological lung injury score, which attributes 68% of the maximal points to the presence or absence of neutrophils in the alveolar and parenchymal space (29), only decreased to values comparable to those detected in LPS-primed mice without platelet transfusions, a finding that is consistent with the conclusion that ASM-targeted interventions during platelet storage effectively prevented the detrimental effects of aged platelet transfusions (2nd hit), but did not alleviate the inflammatory response to prior LPS priming (1st hit).

Partial prevention of the inflammatory response may, in addition, also in part be attributable to the fact that, although ASM and/or ceramide-targeted interventions have been extensively demonstrated to have barrierprotective effects in lung injury (9,41,67), their effectiveness in preventing or attenuating neutrophil activation and recruitment is less clear.

In combination, 1) the demonstrated elevated ceramide levels in aged human platelets (known to be associated with TRALI), 2) mouse platelet pool ceramide levels directly correlating with disease severity, and 3) blockade of the primary ceramide-forming enzyme ASM in stored platelets leading to decreased ceramide levels and prevention of TRALI strongly suggest the functional relevance of ASM-derived ceramide in the pathogenesis of TRALI.
However, it should be considered that direct proof for the involvement of ceramide per se is still lacking.

In isolated rat lungs, infusion of C2:0 ceramide has been shown to increase lung weight as a measure of lung vascular barrier failure (9); however, physiologically more relevant long-chain ceramides such as C16:0, C22:0 or C24:0 evade direct in vivo or in situ testing because of their poor solubility in plasma.

Although the critical relevance of the ceramide-generating enzyme ASM could be demonstrated by both pharmacological and genetic interventions, we can at the present stage not fully exclude the possibility that ASM may promote endothelial barrier disruption in TRALI by a process that is independent of ceramide although the nature of such an effect would be enigmatic.

Platelet numbers, size, and CD41 surface expression remained stable between day 1 and 7 of platelet storage in the absence of bacterial infection, whereas P-selectin expression increased in all groups to values similar to those previously reported for human platelets stored for up to 9 days (8,38).

However, storage time-dependent platelet activation, as indicated by increasing P-selectin expression, was per se not a key trigger for induction of lung injury, as ASM-targeted strategies successfully reduced signs of TRALI without affecting the increase in P-selectin.

ASM-targeted strategies, not only alleviated TRALI symptoms following infusion of 5-day-old platelets, but also allowed for extended duration storage of murine platelets for up to 7 days with less induction of TRALI compared with untreated platelets.

Extension of the longevity of stored platelets thus presents an additional advantage of ASM-targeted interventions, as it may help alleviate the constant need for donation to replenish blood bank inventories because of their rapid expiration for clinical use ranging typically from 3 to 5 days.
Previously 7-day storage of human platelets was undertaken in the US and is presently the practice in the Netherlands (10).
In the US, the FDA limited storage to 5 days based on concerns of bacterial contamination (18).
As storage and bacterial detection methods improve (33), blood banks are again considering longer durations of storage such as 7 days (6,16).

For the present study, we obtained platelets from platelet-rich plasma, as they resemble pooled plasma-derived human platelet products that are used in blood banks around the world, such as those in Canada, and are considered to be associated with a greater risk for induction of lung injury than nonplasmacontaining products (17).

With that in mind, our preparation and storage method was modeled after human preparation of pooled plasma-derived platelets with the exception of not using storage bags but rather blood collection tubes.

Although caution is clearly warranted when comparing rodent to human platelets, our present findings may help facilitate the extension of platelet storage time in general and in particular with respect to pooled plasma-containing platelet products.

Because ceramide reduces homeostatic NO formation and activates TRPC6 channels, which contribute to endothelial barrier failure as well as lung edema (41,67), and platelets contain abundant ASM, pharmacological manipulation of ASM-dependent ceramide metabolism may represent a promising strategy to prolong the clinical utility of stored platelets.

With evolving technology for detection and prevention of bacterial contamination and ASMbased strategies for increased safety of extended-duration stored platelets in terms of reduced TRALI risk, there may be sufficient rationale to reexamine the recommended maximum storage duration of platelets for clinical practice.
Fig. 1.
Transfusion of aged platelets into lipopolysaccharide (LPS)-primed mice causes transfusionrelated acute lung injury (TRALI).

Group data show wet-to-dry lung weight ratio (A), protein concentration in bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (BAL) (B), myeloperoxidase (MPO) activity in lung tissue (C), and histological features of lung injury on a quantitative scale from 0 (no injury) to 1 (maximal) in recipient BALB/c mice that had been primed with either normal saline (-) or LPS (2 mg/kg i.p.) and then transfused with either normal saline (-), fresh (day 1, D1), or stored (D3, D5) platelets (10 ml/kg of 1 ϫ 10 9 allogeneic murine platelets/ml) 6 h before necropsy (D).

E: representative hematoxylin and eosin (H and E)stained histological micrographs show progressive severity of lung injury with platelet storage time in LPS-primed mice (ϩ/D1-D5) compared with control (Ϫ/Ϫ) and LPS-primed (ϩ/Ϫ) mice without transfusion (scale bar ϭ 100 m).
Group data are means (Ϯ SE) from n ϭ 5-8 animals each; *P Ͻ 0.05 vs. Ϫ/Ϫ sham group; #P Ͻ 0.05 vs. ϩ/Ϫ group; छP Ͻ 0.05 vs. ϩ/D1 group, respectively, by 1-way ANOVA and post hoc Tukey's test.
Fig.2.
Time profile of TRALI following transfusion of stored platelets.

Group data show wet-to-dry lung weight ratio (A) and histological features of lung injury on a quantitative scale from 0 (no injury) to 1 (maximal) in LPS (2 mg/kg i.p.)-primed recipient BALB/c mice transfused with aged, stored platelets (day 5; 10 ml/kg of 1 ϫ 10 9 allogeneic murine platelets/ml) 3, 6, or 24 h before necropsy (B).
C: representative H and E-stained histological micrographs show peak lung injury at 6 h and partial resolution after 24 h (scale bar ϭ 100 m).
Group data are means (Ϯ SE) from n ϭ 5 animals each; *P Ͻ 0.05 vs. 3 h; #P Ͻ 0.05 vs. 6 h, respectively, by 1-way ANOVA and post hoc Tukey's test.
Fig. 3. Recipient inflammation acts as 1st hit to enhance TRALI.

Group data show wet-to-dry lung weight ratio (A), protein concentration in BAL fluid (B), MPO activity in lung tissue (C), and histological features of lung injury on a quantitative scale from 0 (no injury) to 1 (maximal) in recipient BALB/c mice that had been primed with either normal saline (-) or LPS (2 mg/kg i.p.) and then transfused with either normal saline (-) or maximally aged platelets (10 ml/kg of 1 ϫ 10 9 allogeneic murine platelets/ml) 6 h before necropsy (D).

E: representative H and E-stained histological micrographs show overadditive induction of TRALI by the combined effects of LPS priming and transfusion of aged platelets (ϩ/aged) compared with control (Ϫ/Ϫ) and LPS-primed (ϩ/Ϫ) mice without transfusion or transfused mice without LPS priming (-/aged) (scale bar ϭ 100 m).
Group data are means (Ϯ SE) from n ϭ 5-8 animals each; *P Ͻ 0.05 vs. Ϫ/Ϫ sham group; #P Ͻ 0.05 vs. ϩ/Ϫ group; छP Ͻ 0.05 vs. -/aged group, respectively, by 1-way ANOVA and post hoc Tukey's test.
Fig. 4. Macrophage inflammatory protein-2␣ (MIP-2␣) in BAL fluid.

Group data show MIP-2␣ concentration in BAL as measured by ELISA in recipient BALB/c mice that had been primed with either normal saline (-) or LPS (2 mg/kg i.p.) and then transfused with either normal saline (-) or aged, stored (day 5) platelets (10 ml/kg of 1 ϫ 10 9 allogeneic murine platelets/ml) 6 h before necropsy.
Group data are means Ϯ SE from n ϭ 5 animals each; *P Ͻ 0.05 vs. Ϫ/Ϫ sham group; #P Ͻ 0.05 vs. LPS/-group; छP Ͻ 0.05 vs. -/aged group, respectively, by 1-way ANOVA and post hoc Tukey's test.
Fig. 5. Ceramide accumulates in stored murine platelets as a function of time.
Group data show concentrations of ceramide species C16:0 (A), C18:0 (B), C22:0 (C), C24:0 (D), and C24:1 (E) in platelets of C57BL/6 donor mice as a function of platelet storage for 1-7 days.

Group data are means (Ϯ SE) from n ϭ 4 -8 independent pooled platelet samples each; *P Ͻ 0.05 vs. day 0; #P Ͻ 0.05 vs. day 1; छP Ͻ 0.05 vs. day 3; $P Ͻ 0.05 vs. day 5, respectively, by 1-way ANOVA and post hoc Tukey's test.
Fig. 6.

Acid sphingomyelinase (ASM) inhibition or deletion in stored platelets attenuates TRALI.Group data show wet-to-dry lung weight ratio (A), protein concentration in BAL (B), MPO activity in lung tissue (C), and histological features of lung injury on a quantitative scale from 0 (no injury) to 1 (maximal) in recipient BALB/c mice that had been primed with either normal saline (-) or LPS (2 mg/kg i.p.) and then transfused with either normal saline (-) or 5-day-aged (D5) platelets (10 ml/kg of 1 ϫ 10 9 allogeneic murine platelets/ml) from either C57BL/6 wild-type (WT) mice, ASM-deficient (smpd1 Ϫ/Ϫ ) mice, or WT platelets stored in the presence of the ASM inhibitor ARC39 (10 mol/l) (D).

E: representative H and E-stained histological micrographs show attenuated TRALI in mice transfused with aged platelets from smpd1 Ϫ/Ϫ mice or WT platelets stored with ARC39 compared with aged WT platelets in LPS-primed mice (scale bar ϭ 100 m).

Group data are means (Ϯ SE) from n ϭ 5-10 animals each; *P Ͻ 0.05 vs. Ϫ/Ϫ sham group; #P Ͻ 0.05 vs. ϩ/Ϫ group; छP Ͻ 0.05 vs. ϩ/smpd1 Ϫ/Ϫ ; $P Ͻ 0.05 vs. ϩ/ARC39, respectively, by 1-way ANOVA and post hoc Tukey's test.
Fig.7.
ASM deficiency permits extended storage of platelets with reduced signs of TRALI in recipient mice.

Group data show wet-to-dry lung weight ratio (A), protein concentration in BAL (B), MPO activity in lung tissue (C), and histological features of lung injury on a quantitative scale from 0 (no injury) to 1 (maximal) in recipient BALB/c mice that had been primed with either normal saline (-) or LPS (2 mg/kg i.p.) and then transfused with 7-day-stored (D7) platelets (10 ml/kg of 1 ϫ 10 9 allogeneic murine platelets/ ml) from either C57BL/6 WT mice or ASMdeficient smpd1 Ϫ/Ϫ mice (smpd1 Ϫ/Ϫ ) (D).

E: representative H and E-stained histological micrographs show attenuated TRALI in mice transfused with 7-day-stored platelets from smpd1 Ϫ/Ϫ mice compared with WT platelets in LPS-primed mice (scale bar ϭ 100 m).
Group data are means (Ϯ SE) from n ϭ 5-8 animals each; *P Ͻ 0.05 vs. Ϫ/Ϫ sham group; #P Ͻ 0.05 vs. ϩ/smpd1 Ϫ/Ϫ D7, respectively, by 1-way ANOVA and post hoc Tukey's test.
Fig. 8. ASM-targeted interventions reduce ceramide accumulation in stored platelets.

Group data show concentrations of ceramide species C16:0 (A) as a function of platelet storage time for 1-7 days and C22:0 (B) and C24:0 (C) for 7-day-stored platelets in platelets from C57BL/6 donor mice (WT), WT C57BL/6 platelets stored in the presence of the ASM inhibitor ARC39 (10 mol/l; ARC39), or platelets from ASM-deficient smpd1 Ϫ/Ϫ mice (smpd1 Ϫ/Ϫ ).

Group data are means (Ϯ SE) from n ϭ 4 -8 independent pooled platelet samples each; *P Ͻ 0.05 vs. WT by 2-way ANOVA and post hoc Bonferroni's test for A and *P Ͻ 0.05 vs. WT by 1-way ANOVA and post hoc Tukey's test for B and C.
Characteristics of stored platelets as a function of storage time and ASM
